meanings.definition: To subject (a structure) to a stress greater than that which will be imposed on it in use, in order to improve its performance.
meanings.sent1: The engineers decided to prestress the bridge to make it stronger.
meanings.sent2: Contractors often prestress concrete beams to enhance their durability.
meanings.sent3: The building was so stressed out, it needed a little extra prestress to keep it together.
meanings.sent4: She felt like she needed to prestress her mind before the big exam.
meanings.sent5: The coach prestressed the importance of teamwork to the players.

meanings.definition: The stress applied to a structure before it is subjected to the service loads.
meanings.sent1: The prestress in the cables helped support the weight of the structure.
meanings.sent2: Engineers carefully calculated the amount of prestress needed for the project.
meanings.sent3: The prestress in the foundation gave the building a strong base to stand on.
meanings.sent4: The prestress in the steel beams acted like a safety net for the entire structure.
meanings.sent5: The prestress in the walls prevented any cracks from forming under pressure.
